column1: Feature Isolation for Hypothesis Testing in Retinal Imaging: An Ischemic Stroke Prediction Case Study

column2: Zhan Wei Lim@National University of Singapore
column4: Daniel S.W. Ting@Duke National University of Singapore Medical School
column5: Tien Yin Wong@Duke National University of Singapore Medical School
column6: Mong Li Lee@National University of Singapore

column1: Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of death and long-term disability that is difficult to predict reliably. Retinal fundus photography has been proposed for stroke risk assessment
column2: due to its non-invasiveness and the similarity between retinal and cerebral microcirculations
column3: with past studies claiming a correlation between venular caliber and stroke risk. However
column4: it may be that other retinal features are more appropriate. In this paper
column5: extensive experiments with deep learning on six retinal datasets are described. Feature isolation involving segmented vascular tree images is applied to establish the effectiveness of vessel caliber and shape alone for stroke classification
column6: and dataset ablation is applied to investigate model generalizability on unseen sources. The results suggest that vessel caliber and shape could be indicative of ischemic stroke
column7: and sourcespecific features could influence model performance.
